0: CINCINNATI -- Hamilton County Prosecutor Joseph Deters is launching a comprehensive investigation to determine what exactly went wrong that led to the death of a 16-year-old Seven Hills student in the school parking lot Tuesday afternoon. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The young man was trapped in the third row bench seat, and it is called positional asphyxiation," Deters said. "We are actively trying to identify experts to assist in us in this investigation." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Hamilton County Sheriff Jim Neil and Cincinnati Police Chief Eliot Isaac have also ordered investigations into the incident. Isaac said one 911 operator has been placed on administrative leave. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Just after 3 p.m. Tuesday, 16-year-old Kyle Jacob Plush called 911 panicking. Over the course of a three-minute call in which he gasped, cried repeatedly for help and struggled to communicate with the operator, he relayed that he was trapped inside his car in the parking lot of Seven Hills School. A source close to the investigation said Plush was going to get his tennis racket from the van when he became trapped. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I probably don't have much time left, so tell my mom I love her if I die," he said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The call ended; when officers checking out the scene attempted to call back, it went to voicemail. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR RELATED TIMELINE: Here's what we know in boy's van death NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A deputy sent to the scene soon after called in to report that he couldn't find anyone trapped in a van. He questioned if the call had been a prank. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Plush was there. He called again. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "This is not a joke," he said. "I am trapped inside a gold Honda Odyssey van in the parking lot of Seven Hills. ... Send officers immediately. I'm almost dead." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR RELATED: Did a defective van kill Seven Hills student? NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR At several points in the second three-minute call, during which the operator does not respond and loud banging or heavy breathing can be heard, he attempts to call on the Siri automated iPhone assistant without success. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR WCPO is not publishing Plush's 911 calls due to their graphic, disturbing nature and out of respect to his family. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Nick Francis, director of Experiential Learning at Seven Hills School, said in a 911 call a security guard contacted him and told him to call 911 because they found a kid in his car. Francis told the dispatcher he wasn’t at the school, but they had been “missing a kid.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I got a call from a security guy there because we were trying to find this kid, and he just all of a sudden called me, 'Nick we found him. Call 911, he's in his car,’” Francis told the dispatcher. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Around 9 p.m., according to police, a family member discovered him dead inside the van -- a death Hamilton County Coroner Lakshmi Sammarco would rule accidental "asphyxia caused by chest compression." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Something -- neither Sammarco nor Lt. Steve Saunders indicated what -- had pressed so hard against Plush's chest that he suffocated. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The information released by police Wednesday afternoon did not clarify the reason the first deputy to respond was not able to find Plush's van or where Plush had been inside of it. Plush's uncle, who declined to share his name or speak on camera, said Wednesday night the 911 system failed the "great kid" who had been his nephew. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Plush was a student at Seven Hills, spokeswoman Christine Hedges said Wednesday morning. The school has grief counselors on hand for any student who needs them. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR City Councilwoman Amy Murray, whose child also attends Seven Hills, also promised a full investigation into the incident on Thursday on WLW. She called it a "sad, sad day." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cincinnati Councilwoman Amy Murray calls it "heartbreaking". She is promising a full investigation into death of a Seven Hills student. Murray is the parent of a student at the school as well and calls this "a sad, sad day". However, in this case, we have declined to share the name of Plush's uncle in order to protect the family's privacy in the aftermath of the teenager's death.
